case_name: Basti Sugar Mills Ltd. v. the twenty-one persons (respondents)

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 225 of 1963 filed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 225 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the award dated

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from award dated November 26, 1962 of Labour Court, Lucknow, in Adjudication Case No. 68 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated November 26, 1962 of the Labour Court, Lucknow, in Adjudication Case No. 68 of 1962. S. Pathak and D.N. M

facts.text: Twenty-one persons who are respondents engaged from November 21, 1958 to February 5, 1959 in removal of press-mud in sugar factory of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The twenty-one persons who are the respondents in this appeal were engaged from November 21, 1958, to February 5, 1959, in the work of removal of press-mud in the sugar factory belonging to the appellant.

facts.text: Services of twenty-one respondents terminated on February 6, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On February 6, 1959, their services were terminated. It also appears that for the period of work of November 21, 1959, to February 5, 1959, they were paid wages at rates lower than Rs. 55/- per month which was the minimum prescribed wage for workmen of vacuum pan sugar factories of Uttar Pradesh under the Standing Orders dated October 3, 1958, issued by the Government of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Respondents paid wages lower than Rs. 55 per month for period November 21, 1958 to February 5, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: It also appears that for the period of work of November 21, 1959, to February 5, 1959, they were paid wages at rates lower than Rs. 55/- per month which was the minimum prescribed wage for workmen of vacuum pan sugar factories of Uttar Pradesh under the Standing Orders dated October 3, 1958, issued by the Government of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Minimum wage Rs. 55 per month prescribed under Standing Orders dated October 3, 1958 for workmen of vacuum pan sugar factories of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: they were paid wages at rates lower than Rs. 55/- per month which was the minimum prescribed wage for workmen of vacuum pan sugar factories of Uttar Pradesh under the Standing Orders dated October 3, 1958, issued by the Government of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Governor of Uttar Pradesh referred dispute to Labour Court, Lucknow on July 31, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On July 31, 1962, the Governor of Uttar Pradesh referred to the Labour Court, Lucknow, a dispute between these respondents and the Basti Sugar Mills Ltd. In this the Basti Sugar Mills Ltd., was described as the employers and the respondents as their workmen.

facts.text: Dispute between respondents (workmen) and Basti Sugar Mills Ltd. (employers).

anchor.surface_text: a dispute between these respondents and the Basti Sugar Mills Ltd. In this the Basti Sugar Mills Ltd., was described as the employers and the respondents as their workmen. The matters in dispute were thus mentioned in the order of reference -

facts.text: Appellant contended that 21 workmen not employed by management but by contractor Banarsi Das for removal of press-mud.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytended that these 21 workmen were number employed by the management of the sugar mills. The appellants case was that the work of removal of press-mud had been given by the Company to a companytractor, Banarsi Das, and that these 21 men were employed by that companytractor to do the work.

facts.text: Banarsi Das left the work on February 6, 1959, and terminated services of the 21 workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The management of the Company, it was said, had numberhing to do with these men. Banarsi Das left the work on February 6, 1959, and the termination of the services of these workmen was made by him.

facts.text: Respondents contended they were employed directly by management of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents through their Union companytended, on the companytrary, that they had been employed directly by the management of the Company. On a companysideration of the evidence the Labour Court accepted the appellants case that the work of removal of press-mud was being done through the companytractor Banarsi Das and it was Banarsi Das under whom these 21 persons were employed.

facts.text: Labour Court accepted that work done through contractor Banarsi Das and 21 persons employed by him.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of the evidence the Labour Court accepted the appellants case that the work of removal of press-mud was being done through the companytractor Banarsi Das and it was Banarsi Das under whom these 21 persons were employed.

facts.text: Labour Court held appellant is employer per definition in sub-cl. (iv) of s. 2(i) of UP Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: It further held that in view of the definition of employer in sub-cl.  iv  of s. 2  i  of the Uttar Pradesh Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, the appellant was in law the employer of these 21 persons.

facts.text: Labour Court held workmen entitled to benefit of Standing Orders regarding minimum wages and reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: It held accordingly that they were entitled to the benefit of the Standing Orders regarding minimum wages and were also entitled to reinstatement.

facts.text: Labour Court ordered payment at Rs. 55 per month from February 6, 1959 to end of crushing season 1958-59.

anchor.surface_text: In that view the Labour Court ordered,  a  payment to the Workmen at the rate of Rs. 551 per month from February 6, 1959 upto the end of the crushing season of 1958 59  b  reinstatement of the workmen if number already employed by the Company in the crushing season of 1962-63

facts.text: Labour Court ordered reinstatement if not already employed in 1962-63 crushing season.

anchor.surface_text: b  reinstatement of the workmen if number already employed by the Company in the crushing season of 1962-63 and  c  payment of difference of wages companyputed at the rate of Rs. 55/- per month and Re. I - per day in the case of Ram Ujagar and 14 annas per day in the case of other workmen for the period November 21, 1958 to February 5, 1959.

facts.text: Labour Court ordered payment of wage difference for November 21, 1958 to February 5, 1959, at Rs.55/month, Re.1/day for Ram Ujagar, 14 annas/day for others.

anchor.surface_text: c  payment of difference of wages companyputed at the rate of Rs. 55/- per month and Re. I - per day in the case of Ram Ujagar and 14 annas per day in the case of other workmen for the period November 21, 1958 to February 5, 1959. Against this order of the Labour Court the present appeal has been filed by the Company with the special leave of this Court.

facts.text: Appeal filed by Company with special leave of Supreme Court.

Mr. Pathak wanted to raise a new point based on the provisions of cl. K of the Standing Orders. That clause provides that a seasonal workman who has worked or, but for illness or any other unavoidable cause, would have worked under a factory during the whole of the second half of the last preceding season will be employed by the factory in the current season.
